description: From Late Latin (circulus) aequator (diei et noctis).

entries.meaning: (geography, often “the Equator”) An imaginary great circle around Earth, equidistant from the two poles, and dividing earth's surface into the northern and southern hemisphere.
examples: Baishui is about as close to the equator as Tampa, Florida.

entries.meaning: (astronomy) A similar great circle on any sphere, especially on a celestial body, or on other reasonably symmetrical three-dimensional body.
The midline of any generally spherical object, such as a fruit or vegetable, that has identifiable poles.
examples: Slice the onion through the equator.
